but yeah this is the this is the open events effort this open event is a vendor-neutral common definition for
event data the why we're doing this or the problem statement is that event data
being transported across environments is increasingly common but platforms that publish event data like major
infrastructure as a service providers and even software's and service companies tend to describe events
differently all they all really have their own formats for event data and this hinders the portability of events
of this data as well as their subscribers like the functions that might be subscribing to these events and
limits the productivity we think we can achieve from event data overall I'm sorry solution in this is to come up
with a common event definition a common kind of format a way of describing events and see if we can get adoption
throughout the industry and the broad goals of this are to ease interoperability between services a lot
of big platforms that publish events are even having a hard time getting all their teams to follow the same format so
easy interoperability between services in between between teams but easy
interoperability between platforms as well kind of multi cloud scenarios or SAS to cloud scenarios also easing
interoperability between legacy systems and new systems getting data out of those old systems and potentially into
the cloud to be processed on something like serverless compute also improving developer experience you know we our
company makes the serverless framework we hear this all the time developers just want like a consistent format for
events especially because a lot of them are contemplating multi-cloud scenarios and writing functions that sit on
different clouds and even maybe on some of the kubernetes based service implementations out there and just
having a vent data come in in a consistent format or shape I would be so helpful for them really woody use the designing and
testing and monitoring of their systems overall enabling tooling if we can come up with a common way of a common format
for events we think there's a lot of opportunities for a tooling around this and creating an ecosystem of tools
around this so tracing of event data better and better understanding of where it came from where it went
tracing it throughout event-driven workflows event registries is something that we hear commonly in the service
community people who have a lot of functions and are receiving a lot of event data wish that they could have some type of experience that almost
looks like REST API documentation or a developer boot for an API management
solution that shows all the REST API endpoints and all the all the data and
parameters that they accept so something like that for events as well I mean overall just more productivity I think
that we're still and we're still in the beginning of this serverless or event room and computing Renaissance here and
if we could come up with a common way of describing these events I think it would accelerate all that so these are our
goals with this right now for the past few months we've been out there rallying
support for this and we've gotten a ton of support honestly all the people we've chatted with on this list here but
companies who have expressed very strong sincere interest in this our Amazon
Google Microsoft our companies in there IBM Oracle Iguazu of course Alibaba
Red Hat pivotal and more so we've got a lot of great stakeholders now the
challenge with this though is that if we're going to get the industry to adopt a common way of describing events it's
going to require significant investment on behalf of the industry especially the
larger players and people who publish a lot of event data or people who provide some type of great compute service for
subscribing to that event data so trying to figure out how to get this adopted it's been something we've been thinking
a lot about and our solution has been let's go around to all the major influencers and try and assemble like a
scope and get sorry try and get their priorities from them surface those priorities make sure we understand what
they actually need in this format to contemplate adopting it the future so that's what we've been
doing mostly through a lot of private conversations probably had about 40 or 50 meetings about this over the past few
months definitely been a lot of coordination of logistics lining up calls and getting people together and we
actually were able to just do and have a great initial conversation / working
session yesterday in Seattle and it was between Amazon Google Microsoft we all
sat down together which I think was kind of an extraordinary event and just a
testament to how much interest there is in this whole thing and how great and collaborative these companies are over
all but we all sat down and we had a great conversation around their priorities how they felt about this what
they need in this specification in order to adopt it from that we assembled a scope and all this happened yesterday a
lot of this data it just came in and we're going to get this into the PR into
the servlets working group repo next I just haven't had a chance to because we just we just finished that that long
working session but we have assembled a scope and the first thing we agreed to
focus on was just coming up with a set of event metadata attributes this is like the envelope that would ship with
your event and these metadata attributes should focus on a few things number one they should offer a basic description of
the event and the data it carries for example an event type is this a customer created events or was there a product
purchased events and also versioning should be a big part of that also who we
identify event mated metadata attributes that are already implemented across all the publishers platforms so when we look
we looked at data looked at Microsoft's event grid we looked at cloud watch events on Amazon and kind of what Google
cloud functions was accepting as well and we could see so much so many parallels between the event data that
these platforms have they're just naming them different things and some of them do have think differently about the
semantics of those but we think that there's a lot of low-hanging fruit in just identifying all the things that
people are already using and assembling them into one one thing that people agree upon also can these
metadata attributes to be delivered separately from event data in a serialized fashion for example in in
JSON or also can the metadata attributes to be delivered kind of separately in transport headers like in something in a
in a protocol or transport mechanism like HTTP or Kafka so that was a big
concern Iran has really pushed this and helped us think I think in the beginning we
were focused we had a very kind of limited service compute perspective but this is bigger than that and events are going to come
from a lot of different places we have to think how these metadata attributes are going to be shipped and all these
different transport mechanisms so we need to figure that out and include in the metadata a description of the
transport or protocol as well as the encoding also something else that the
providers have all said that is important to them is they need a way in the metadata to actually extend the
attributes that you could put in there in like a safe way so that they could test out so we could test out new
features in the event metadata like experiment experiment with it as well as
a lot of these platforms have proprietary features specific features or unique features that other platforms
don't have and they want to make sure they have a place to stick those those features this is very much like if
you're familiar with swagger or open API they have an extensions concept where you could put on specific data that's
not supported by the specification and you just mark it as an extension using a
prefix we think that kind of going along with some of the conventions in open API
might be a good idea so we tried to use some of their names but this is a big this is a big priority for everybody
allowing for evolution of the payload schema as well as the open events definition so this just goes back to
versioning versioning is something that we need both at the payload level to describe the event data as well as the
specification the open event specification itself because that's also going to evolve and then also a way to
embed event metadata at different stages along the routes of an event being delivered by
middleware so a router could potentially add transport or information or something like that so metadata
attributes this is you know when we talk about what is a common definition for events it's really it really comes down
largely to these metadata attributes and that's what we're focused on and these are just the key themes that were
